title: Butterkuchen Recipe
description: A yeasted German-style coffee cake with a cinnamon sugar topping.
body: ​ Skip to content Allrecipes Search Please fill out this field. Search the site Please fill out this field. About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European German Butterkuchen 4.2 (33) 30 Reviews 7 Photos A yeasted German-style coffee cake with a cinnamon sugar topping. Submitted by JBS BOX Updated on April 7, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 7 7 7 7 Prep Time: 1 hr 30 mins Cook Time: 30 mins Total Time: 2 hrs Servings: 24 Yield: 1 9x13-inch cake Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 24 servings 2 (.25 ounce) packages dry yeast ½ cup water ¾ cup milk ½ cup white sugar 1 teaspoon salt ½ cup butter 4 cups all-purpose flour 3 eggs ½ cup butter 1 cup white sugar ½ teaspoon ground cinnamon Directions Butter a 9x13 inch pan and set aside. In a small mixing bowl, dissolve yeast in warm water. Let stand until creamy, about 10 minutes. Place milk, 1/2 cup sugar, salt and 1/2 cup butter in saucepan. Heat until sugar dissolves and butter melts. Cool to lukewarm. Add dissolved yeast and set aside. In large bowl combine flour, eggs and yeast mixture. Stir until smooth and blended. Pour into a buttered 9x13 inch pan, spreading dough evenly. Let rise in warm place for 45 minutes. Meanwhile, preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). In a small bowl, combine 1/2 cup butter, 1 cup sugar and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon. mix together and sprinkle over the dough. Bake in preheated oven for 30 minutes, or until the top is golden and syrupy. I Made It Print 36 home cooks made it! Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Butterkuchen 01 of 07 Photo by  Kim 02 of 07 Photo by  Kim 04/05/2024 I thought this turned out rather well. I used rapid rise yeast in place of active dry; so I proofed it slightly differently. I heated the water and milk together, along with a pinch of sugar, and mixed the yeast into that. While it was proofing, I added the flour, sugar, and salt to a mixing bowl, and made a well in the center. I poured the melted butter, eggs, and yeast mixture into that well, then stirred to combine. I let the dough rest for 10 minutes before pouring into the buttered 9x13 pan. And instead of mixing the butter/sugar/cinnamon together for the topping, I cubed the butter, then dimpled the bread and placed a butter cube into each dimple. Then sprinkled the cinnamon-sugar mixture over the top of everything (I only used 1/2 cup sugar with 1/2 tsp cinnamon). I let that rise for 1 hr, then baked it for 30 minutes at 350 degrees F. It came out great; moist, tender, flavorful. But you must eat this bread/cake while it's still warm! The flavor and texture are no where near as good when it's cooled; so serve warm, and be sure to reheat any leftovers before eating. Thank you for sharing your recipe! 03 of 07 Photo by  Nina Greipel 10/22/2019 One of my favorite cakes to bake! Time consuming, but not at all difficult. Plus, it’ll make your oven and kitchen smell yummy!! 04 of 07 Photo by  caneisha 11/06/2014 05 of 07 Photo by  Cindybee 03/06/2014 This was fairly easy to make and turned out well but it's VERY rich. I remember my German mother's Butterkuchen to be much lighter. Still, worth a try. 06 of 07 Photo by  MattOlay V-H 03/05/2012 The best part is the topping, which I had adjusted the sugar by the way because I thought that was way too much. I have also cut the dough down to half just to test it out using a smaller baking pan. It rose beautifully (1 hr of rising) and the surface dotted with bubbles.... a good sign. Well, the results came out dry and bland. I think this would be good as a bar. It was just too much dry dough, so next time I would use a 9x13 pan using half the recipe. 07 of 07 Photo by  Sarah-May 03/11/2011 This is tasty and simple to make. A very good yeast first-timer recipe. It needed more spice in my opinion but was soft and delicious. 1 You’ll Also Love Honey Cake II 18 Ratings Nana's Cranberry Kuchen 10 Ratings German Marble Cake 86 Ratings Chocolate Sauerkraut Cake II 22 Ratings German Lemon Cake 55 Ratings German Strawberry Roll 5 Ratings Moist German Sheet Pan Apple Cake Honey Cake I 24 Ratings Easy German Apple Sheet Cake 6 Ratings German Apple Sheet Cake 1 Rating Zwetschgendatschi (German Plum Sheet Cake) 6 Ratings Käsesahnetorte (German Yogurt Mousse Cake) 1 Rating Reisfladen (Rice Pudding Cake) 1 Rating Easy German Apple Streusel Pie 19 Ratings Bavarian-Style Apple Torte 15 Ratings Sugar Zwieback 10 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: JBS BOX
instructions: Butter a 9x13 inch pan and set aside. In a small mixing bowl, dissolve yeast in warm water. Let stand until creamy, about 10 minutes. Place milk, 1/2 cup sugar, salt and 1/2 cup butter in saucepan. Heat until sugar dissolves and butter melts. Cool to lukewarm. Add dissolved yeast and set aside.;In large bowl combine flour, eggs and yeast mixture. Stir until smooth and blended. Pour into a buttered 9x13 inch pan, spreading dough evenly. Let rise in warm place for 45 minutes. Meanwhile, preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).;In a small bowl, combine 1/2 cup butter, 1 cup sugar and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon. mix together and sprinkle over the dough. Bake in preheated oven for 30 minutes, or until the top is golden and syrupy.
